H0.text: Meiosis is the series of events analogous to mitosis that arrange and separate chromosomes and chromatids into daughter cells.

H1.text: Apoptosis is a process analogous to mitosis, involving a series of events that arrange and separate chromosomes and chromatids into daughter cells.

H2.text: Inhibition is a process analogous to mitosis, consisting of a series of events that arrange and separate chromosomes and chromatids into daughter cells.

H3.text: Digestion is a process, analogous to mitosis, that involves a series of events arranging and separating chromosomes and chromatids into daughter cells.

A4.text: During meiosis II, the cohesion between sister chromatids is released and they segregate from one another, as during mitosis

A5.text: DNA replication is followed by two rounds of cell division to produce four daughter cells, each with half the number of chromosomes as the original parent cell
